body:
maybe pluggable views could be a solution. "files" is the core, but an image view or a audio streaming view, even a calendar view, could be added. these views might only show a certain kind of files, present them in a unique way and still offer access to the core functionality. different file management views could be implemented like this as well.

i think a file centric system is more desirable, since it offers the mixing of arbitrary data and greater expressiveness.

thatâ€™s essentially the way it is now. â»picturesâ« is the image view, â»musicâ« is the audio streaming view. and thatâ€™s where my point is: these pictures and music views currently are inferior in functionality to the files â€“ which is a problem if you actually want to use them.

the difference is that calendar, contacts, news etc are not stored in the file system but in the database. would also make little sense to store events, contacts and feeds together with files as thatâ€™s not done in any system.

btw @despens good to have you over here. :)

the problem is, i think, that the views are separated from the files and their ordering can be different. if there would be different "templates" for views that could be used for the files app, and the files app would remember in which directory what view was activated, something interesting could be possible ... especially if the files core exports its functions to all other view templates. even a calendar or contacts view would work. (there is some prior art, http://www.nemo-docs.com/ or the free software predecessor http://www.iola.dk/nemo/ )

![views](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/571494/807139/05bcd83a-ee49-11e2-9807-6975e98036ee.png)

and, hi @jancborchardt, i know you hate balsamiq, but imagine i would have to scan this! :)

hmm. the media player, calendar, rss reader, files app, photo gallery, bookmarks app, contacts and so on are apps that can be switched in the apps navigation. i don't think we should move away from this concept. it's proven, works well and to be honest: from all the user feedback we get. no one has ever complained about this apps navigation. :-)

i think views are a great addition to the files app, but they don't 
really replace the functionality provided by eg. a dedicated music app 
that shows all the albums you have. maybe if we followed the 
xdg-user-dirs spec the music view for the ~/music folder could show all 
albums contained in that folder and it's children. same with ~/pictures 
and the gallery view. i guess most of the dirs specified in the spec 
might make sense:

```
 xdg_desktop_dir="$home/desktop"
 xdg_download_dir="$home/downloads"
 xdg_templates_dir="$home/templates"
 xdg_publicshare_dir="$home/public"
 xdg_documents_dir="$home/documents"
 xdg_music_dir="$home/music"
 xdg_pictures_dir="$home/pictures"
 xdg_videos_dir="$home/videos"
```
 i would rather like a ~/todo folder used by the notes app storing 
files in a somewhat standard todo.txt format: 
http://owncloud.org/todo-txt-for-owncloud-with-todos/ thx @gomez

i can even imagine something like that for ~/bookmarks. maybe in 
netscapes bookmarks.html format: 
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa753582(v=vs.85).aspx

calendar and contacts happen to use sabredav, but they won't fit into 
the filesystem until we save provide them as vcard or ical files. that 
might go with unix 'everythin is a file' doctrine, but i fail to see 
the benefit. they, and the notes app, are in the pim category, which 
imho needs a dedicated app (although i like the calendar view for 
files, mostly recently used files that is ... like zeitgeists activity 
journal).

file centric is a well understood paradigm but not all apps can provide 
a flat file based representation of their content. thinking about this 
i guess this is an evolutionary process. some functionality starts as 
an app (news) and some apps are created to improve interacting with 
special files (gallery, music ...). not all apps should expose their 
data via webdav, eg. the calendar and contacts apps might get confused 
when the ical/vcard files are overwritten via webdav ... i don't know.

i guess we can compare this to the desktop. we have a bunch of files 
there and we have special apps for audio/video playback etc. and we can 
do different things in the file explorer and music player of our 
choice. sharing something in a file centric app such as music, video, 
gallery and todo basically is the same as sharing a file and should be 
implemented the same way. apps storing their data in the database 
(calendar, contacts) share their data with the sharing api and an app 
related share type.

the files app won't go away and i assume many users like to access 
their pictures via webdav. maybe there is even a use case for accessing 
your contacts via ~/addressbook/*name*.vcard...

i think we can only try to come up with a guideline for what users 
might expect of an app over plain file based access.
